The Date and the Meaning of the Vettius Affair
The report of the informer Vettius on the alleged conspiracy against Pompey's life is usually dated between August and October i8 of the year 59.  The incident is fully described in Cicero's letter to Atticus II 24.  That letter appears in correspondence with Atticus in Epirus that is med to be arranged in exact chronological order.  A preceding letter,  II 21,  written on or shortly after July 25,  has seemed to provide a terminus post quern.  A terminus ante quem is supplied by the fact,  attested in Cicero's in Vatinium that at the time of the incident the consular tions had not yet taken place.  Those elections were postponed by Bibulus { ad Att,  II 20,  6 ) to October 18.  My investigations have led me to believe that the terminus post quem is not valid because the letters are not in chronological order,  and that a new terminus post quem and also a much more definite terminus ante quem can be established.  My results,  if they are accepted,  will lead to a revision of the dating of the eight letters written to Atticus in Epirus,  a redating of the Vettius affair,  and possibly to a better understanding of the puzzling incident. 
I shall try first to fix the terminus ante quem.  Ad Atticum II 24 follows immediately upon II 23,  and that letter was written before the tribunitial elections.  In it Cicero urgently pled with Atticus to return.  Cicero expressed the hope that Atticus would come back,  if not before Cicero's enemy Clodius was elected to the tribunate,  certainly after the election had been announced : permagni nostra interest te,  si comitiis non potuerisy at declarato illo esse Romae,  There is no indication that the election had taken place in the interval between letters 23 and 24.  It seems clear that the Vettius incident occurred before Clodius was designated tribune. 
Now although Bibulus postponed the consular elections,  and therefore the choice of praetors,  curule aediles,  and quaestors,  which regularly followed the election of consuls,  there is no justification for the general
I.  25 : L.  Lentulum. . . .  flaminem Martialem,  quod erat eo tempore Gabini tui petitor y tuo indicio op primer e voluisti.
